abstract.para: This document is intended for Rackspace Cloud Feeds™ customers who want to submit a feed to be published by Cloud Feeds.

listitem.para: Published the initial internal release of the Cloud Feeds Publisher's Guide.
Added descriptions for publishing additional feed types.

chapter.title: Defining and publishing events
chapter.para: Rackspace Cloud Feeds™ supports the publication of events that are collected in a feed. Events have a specific format, and you can have multiple types of events in a single feed.
Cloud Feeds uses AtomPub to publish different types of feeds. AtomPub is based on an HTTP transfer of Atom-formatted representations. The Atom format is documented in the Atom Syndication Format.

Cloud Feeds events must be defined using the Common Event Format (CEF). The Usage Measurement Service (UMS) uses CEF for tracking, but CEF can be also used for other events and by third-party event publishers. CEF supports versioning of the event and product nodes through the version attribute, which enables products to release new versions of their schema.
To read the official documentation for the Atom Syndication Format, see RFC 4287. For more information about AtomPub, visit http://atompub.org/.

section.title: Event categories
section.para: Cloud Feeds supports the following event categories:

listitem.para: Usage events record information about how much a resource is being used over a specified time period —for example, how much bandwidth, disk space or CPU cycles are being used.

System events are published to notify subscribers about changes in their environments—for example, a server has been provisioned, an IP address has been released, or an error state has occurred in a VM.
User access events are generated when a user attempts to access a specific API—for example, if a user requests that a server be shut down.
Non user-access events in CADF

section.title: Feed format
section.para: Currently, Cloud Feeds supports feeds in XML format. The feeds and events follow the Atom Syndication Format and the API adheres to the Atom Publication Protocol. A feed has the following structure.
The following table describes each element in a feed.

tr.td: Generated by the publisher. This element contains information about the event that is not product-specific, such as the time and duration of the event and where the event occurred.

Generated by Cloud Feeds. This element is present only when the feed engine is reading the feeds. This element includes information about the feed, such as how to navigate to the next "page" of events.
Generated by the publisher. This element contains product-specific information about the event, such as the server type, IP address, and state.

section.title: Feed validation
section.para: Cloud Feeds supports validation of a feed against a specified schema. You configure the validation settings when you add your feed to the allfeeds.wadl file. For more information, see Adding the feed to the allfeeds.wadl file.
You can specify the following validation settings for a feed.

tr.td: validated
This setting implies that the entire Atom entry is validated by using an XML schema. If no XML schema exists for the atom:content node, the content is verified to be well-formed XML.
product feed

This setting implies that a specific product schema is allowed for this feed and used for validation, in addition to verification that the feed content is valid XML. The content node only allows event nodes that have a specific product schema associated with them. Only the listed product schemas are allowed. For more information, see Defining your product schema.

section.title: Enabling searching on your feed
section.para: Cloud Feeds supports searching for feed entries by a specific category by using a search query as described in Filtering entries by categories.
To enable the searching functionality on your feed, you need to consider the following:

listitem.para: If you use a product node in your feed or your feed uses the Cloud Auditing Data Federation (CADF) standard, the searching functionality is automatically enabled, and you do not need to specify any additional categories to enable searching.
For any other feeds, you need to add the categories with the appropriate category prefix to enable searching. The following table shows a list of common category prefixes:

tr.td: Specifies the tenant ID, taken from the tenantid attribute from the event node.
Specifies the event type.
Specifies the region.
Specifies the data center.

chapter.title: Event node
chapter.para: The event node is the main element of a Cloud Feeds event entry.
The event node contains the following elements:

listitem.para: Event node attributes (predefined)
Product node

chapter.para: Following is an example of an event node.

example.title: Event node exqmple
example.programlisting: <event startTime="2014-07-14T22:19:52Z" endTime="2014-07-14T24:00:00Z" region="DFW" dataCenter="DFW1" type="USAGE" id="8d89673c-c989-11e1-895a-0b3d632a8a89" resourceId="3863d42a-ec9a-11e1-8e12-df8baa3ca440" tenantId="1234" version="2"> <cb-store:product version="1" serviceCode="CloudBackup" serverID="9445" storage="99992827882" resourceType="AGENT"/> </event>

section.title: Event node attributes
section.para: The attributes in the event node are predefined and cannot be changed. The event node consists of the following attributes.

tr.td: event:Username
Specifies the Rackspace agent who is taking action on behalf of the user.
This attribute is optional.
event:Username
Specifies the user name for the sub-account, when applicable.
This attribute is optional.
event:DC

Specifies the data center of the event. If this attribute is not specified, GLOBAL is assumed. GLOBAL implies that the resource is without an assigned data center. For a list of possible values, see Attribute values for event node.

listitem.para: This attribute is optional for some event types.
This attribute is required for events of type USAGE, USAGE_SUMMARY, and USAGE_SNAPSHOT. The value defined for dataCenter must match the value defined for region.

tr.td: event:UTCDateTime

Specifies the time that the event ends. The format must be ISO 8601 format: yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm:ss.SSSZ (Z designates UTC). For an event of type EXIST, the startTime and endTime reflect the event duration for the resource instance. The end time is exclusive — that is, the event occurred up to, but not during the specified value. The end time must occur after the start time.

listitem.para: This attribute is optional.
This attribute is required for events of type USAGE, but is optional for all other event types.
The startTime attribute must also be specified.
The event cannot span 24 hours.

tr.td: event:ENVIRONMENT
Specifies the environment from which the message originated. If this attribute is not specified, PROD is assumed. For a list of possible values, see Attribute values for event node.
This attribute is required for events of type USAGE_SNAPSHOT, but is optional for all other event types.
event:UTCDateTime
Specifies the time of the event, using ISO 8601 format and UTC. Use this attribute instead of startTime and endTime in cases where the event does not have a range.

listitem.para: This attribute is optional.
This attribute cannot coexist with the startTime or endTime attribute.

tr.td: event:UUID
Specifies the UUID for the event record. This value should be UUID version 1, 2, or 4. For more information, see RFC 4122 at http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4122.
This attribute is required.
event:UUID
Specifies a GUID that identifies the event record that this record is updating. This attribute should be used if this event is correcting another event.
This attribute is optional.
event:Region

Specifies the region in which the event is located. If this attribute is not specified, GLOBAL is assumed. GLOBAL implies that the resource is without an assigned region. For a list of possible values, see Attribute values for event node.

listitem.para: This attribute is optional for some event types.
This attribute is required for events of type USAGE, USAGE_SUMMARY, and USAGE_SNAPSHOT. The value defined for region must match the value defined for dataCenter.

tr.td: event:NonEmptyString
Specifies the ID of the resource.
This attribute is required if the resourceType attribute is specified in the product node, but is optional otherwise.
event:NonEmptyString
Specifies the customer-defined name of the resource.
This attribute is optional.
xsd:anyURI
Specifies a URI that uniquely identifies the resource.
This attribute is optional.
event:NonEmptyString
Specifies the action that caused the event.
This attribute is optional.
event:Severity
Specifies the severity of the event. Valid values are INFO, WARNING, and CRITICAL. This is attribute is valid only for system events, not for usage events.
This attribute is optional.
event:UTCDateTime

Specifies the time that the event starts. The format must be ISO 8601 format: yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm:ss.SSSZ (Z designates UTC). The start time is inclusive, which means that the event occurred starting at the start time, not after.

listitem.para: This attribute is required for events of type USAGE, but is optional for all other event types.
The endTime attribute must also be specified.

tr.td: event:NonEmptyString
Specifies the tenant ID of the publisher.
This attribute is optional.
event:EventType

Specifies the type of event. If one of the existing event types fails to produce any feeds, set this attribute to EXTENDED and add an eventType attribute to your product schema. For more information, see Event types.
This attribute is required.
event:NonEmptyString
Specifies the version of the event record.

listitem.para: This attribute is required.
If this attribute is set to 2, the event cannot span beyond midnight as defined in the startTime and endTime attributes.

note.para: The event: prefix in the preceding table denotes a specific namespace. For more information about namespaces, see Selecting a namespace. DC and Username denote type attributes that are defined in the core.xsd schema file. Core.xsd is posted on GitHub at: https://github.com/rackerlabs/standard-usage-schemas/tree/master/core_xsd.

chapter.title: Product node
chapter.para: The product node is located inside of an event node. The product node is custom and differs for every product. It provides product-specific information and details about the resources. Product nodes are defined by using a product schema.
Following is an example of a product node.

example.title: Product node example
example.programlisting: <sample:product serviceCode="EmailAppsMSService" version="1" key="(domain=5002_domain_2.com)|(service=5002_domain_2.com)" productType="lync" operation="UPDATE" status="COMPLETED" request="HTTP GET" response="200"> <sample:dependent key="(domain=1002_domain_200.com)|(service=1002_domain_100.com)"/> <sample:dependent key="(domain=2002_domain_200.com)|(service=2002_domain_200.com)"/> </sample:product>

section.title: Product schema node
section.para: The product schema is a proprietary, simplified schema format that defines the product node for an event by using XML. This schema enables someone to define a product event without knowing the XML Schema format.
During the build process, the product schema file is transformed into an actual XML Schema file, which is then integrated with Cloud Feeds and validates events when they are posted.
The product schema format has the following features:

listitem.para: • Product schemas can be versioned and multiple versions can co-exist on a feed. This feature enables products to extend their initial format. For more information, see Versioning.
Product nodes can support attributes of several different types, such as strings, dates, numeric types, and values in lists.

Product nodes can support attribute groups, which allows related attributes to be collected into a single node. Several instances of an attribute group may exist in a single product node, giving users the ability to create maps of object types. For a list of allowed data types, see Allowed data types.

section.para: For more information on how to create the final product schema file, see Definining your product schema.
The following table lists the attributes for the product schema node.

tr.td: xsd:dayTimeDuration
Specifies a duration of one of the aggregation periods.

listitem.para: This attribute is required for events of type USAGE.
The list of time periods specified in aggregationPeriods must sum to exactly 24 hours.

tr.td: xsd:boolean

If this attribute is set to true, the attributes are grouped by the resource ID. This group implies that the product is being charged per resource. If this attribute is set to false, attributes are grouped by the tenant ID. This attribute is set to true by default.

listitem.para: This attribute is optional.
If this attribute is set to true, the resourceTypes attribute must be defined.

tr.td: xsd:anyURI
Specifies the namespace for the schema. The namespace must be unique for each product. The same namespace can be used between product schema versions. For more information, see Selecting a namespace.
This attribute is required.
Boolean
The RANEnrichmentStrategy by which the tenant ID is mapped to a Rackspace Account Number (RAN)
This attribute is required for all events of type USAGE.
schema:NameList

Contains a whitespace-separated list of the resource types defined in the product schema (for example, SITES_EMAIL). A product schema must specify at least one resource type if the groupByResource attribute is set to true.
This attribute is optional.
xsd:Name

Specifies the name that uniquely identifies the product or service. The value must be a single word; no whitespaces are allowed. The name is used to construct Atom categories for events of this type—for example, EmailAppsMSService.

listitem.para: This attribute is required.
Each product schema must define a service code attribute that uniquely identifies the product.

tr.td: usage:TypeList
Specifies the types of messages that are applicable to this schema, for example, USAGE_SUMMARY. The default value is USAGE.

listitem.para: This attribute is optional.
For more information, see Event types.

tr.td: xsd:string
Specifies the version of this particular product schema. Any sort of version string is allowed. Each product schema must have a unique version.
This attribute is optional.
xsd:string
Specifies the URL for your feed.
This attribute is required.

section.para: When the product schema runs through the internal build process, a product XSD file is generated. The product schema consists of zero or more attributes and zero or more attribute groups, each of which can contain custom attributes.
The following example shows a sample product schema with multiple attributes and an attribute group defined.

section.title: Attribute node
section.para: The attribute node declares an attribute for a product., such as the name of the product. Attributes are defined in the product schema. The attribute node is a child of the product node.

The XML attributes of the attribute element can consist of different data types, such as strings or integers. Product attributes can vary in their definitions, but they usually contain the XML attributes described in the following table.

table.caption: Common XML attributes for the attribute node

tr.td: schema:TokenList
Specifies an optional whitespace-separated list of allowed values.
This attribute is optional.
xsd:string
Specifies the default value of the attribute, if it has a default value. Only optional attributes can have default values.
This attribute is optional.
xsd:string

Specifies the human-readable name for the attribute that can be used for reports, invoices, and so on. The display name does not have the same constraints as the name attribute. This attribute can contain spaces. If this optional attribute is not specified, the name attribute is used in reports, invoices, and so on.
This attribute is optional.
xsd:string
Specifies the fixed value of the attribute, if it has a fixed value.
This attribute is optional.
schema:MinMaxType
Specifies the minimum value allowed in the numeric type. The value is inclusive.

listitem.para: This attribute is for numeric types only.
This attribute is optional.

tr.td: schema:MinMaxType
Specifies the minimum value allowed in the numeric type. The value is inclusive.

listitem.para: This attribute is for numeric types only.
This attribute is optional.

tr.td: xsd:integer

Specifies the maximum length of a string. Note: if minLength is not set, it defaults to 0, which implies that empty strings are valid. If empty strings are not valid, ensure that minLength is set to a value of greater than 0.

listitem.para: This attribute is for string types only.
This attribute is optional.

tr.td: xsd:integer

Specifies the minimum length of a string. Note: if minLength is not set, it defaults to 0, which implies that empty strings are valid. If empty strings are not valid, ensure that minLength is set to a value of greater than 0.

listitem.para: This attribute is for string types only.
If this attribute is defined, the maxLength attribute is also required.
This attribute defaults to 0.
This attribute is optional.

tr.td: string
Specifies the name of the attribute. This value cannot have spaces.
This attribute is required.
Boolean
If this attribute is set to true, then the attribute value is not shown to the public. The default value is false.
This attribute is optional.
Boolean
If this attribute is set to true, then a category generated for every event based on this attribute's value. The default value is false.
This attribute is optional.
schema:TypeList
Specifies the data types that are applicable to this attribute — for example string or unsignedInt. For more information, see Allowed data types.
This attribute is required.
schema:Use
Specifies whether the product attribute is optional, required, or synthesized.
This attribute is optional, but if it is not specified, the product attribute is labeled as optional.
usage:TypeList

This attribute is valid only with events of the following types: USAGE, CREATE, DELETE. Currently, extended event types are not supported. This attribute should reference a type from the type attribute.

listitem.para: This attribute is optional.
This attribute cannot have the value EXTENDED.

tr.td: schema:NameList

The attribute is valid only with events that reference the type of resource specified. This is a whitespace-separated list. The items on this list must be referenced in the resourceType attribute in the product node.
This attribute is optional.

section.para: Following is an example of an attribute for a product schema.

example.title: Attribute example
example.programlisting: <attribute name="key" type="string" minLength="1" maxLength="1024" use="required"> Specifies the key of the object that this event corresponds to. </attribute>

section.title: Attribute group
section.para: A product schema can contain zero or more attribute groups. An attribute group collects related attributes in a single node. Several instances of an attribute group can exist in a single product node, giving users the ability to create maps of object types. An attribute group can contain up to 50 attributes.
The following table lists the XML attributes that can be set in an attribute group.

table.caption: XML attributes for the attribute group

tr.td: string
Describes the attribute group.
This attribute is required.
schema:MaxOccurs
Specifies the maximum occurrence of the attribute group. The default value is 1.
This attribute is optional.
schema:MinOccurs
Specifies the minimum occurrence of the attribute group. The default value is 1.
This attribute is optional.
xsd: Name
Specifies the name of the attribute group.
This attribute is required.

section.para: Following is an example of a product schema that contains an attribute group.

example.title: Attribute group within product schema example
example.programlisting: <productSchema xmlns="http://docs.rackspace.com/core/usage/schema" namespace="http://docs.rackspace.com/event/emailapps_msservice" version="1" serviceCode="EmailAppsMSService" type="INFO" > <description> Specifies events for the Email and Apps Microsoft Service. </description> <attribute name="key" type="string" minLength="1" maxLength="1024" use="required"> Specifies the key of the object that this event corresponds to. </attribute> <attribute name="productType" type="string" use="required"> Specifies the MS Service product that this event corresponds to. </attribute> <attribute name="operation" type="string" use="required"> Specifies the operation that is performed on the resource that this event corresponds to. </attribute> <attribute name="status" type="Name" allowedValues="COMPLETED ERROR" use="required"> Specifies the status of the operation that is performed on the resource that this event corresponds to. </attribute> <attribute name="request" type="string" minLength="1" maxLength="20000" use="required"> Specifies the request that this event corresponds to. </attribute> <attribute name="response" type="string" minLength="1" maxLength="20000" use="optional"> Specifies the response for the above request. </attribute> <attributeGroup name="dependent" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"> <description> Specifies the list of all dependent objects for an event. For example, in mailbox-related events, since the mailbox has to be under a domain, a domain object can be listed as one of the dependents. </description> <attribute name="key" type="string" minLength="1" maxLength="1024" use="required"> Specifies the key of the dependent objects. </attribute> </attributeGroup> </productSchema>

section.title: XPath assertion node
section.para: XPath assertion nodes enable you to add further checks to your event by using xPath assertions.

While the basic attribute and attributeGroup schema definitions enable you to define most product events, you can create additional custom rules by using XPath assertions and the XPath language. For example, there might be a case when the serverID attribute of a product node is required only when the external condition evaluates to true. This case cannot be enumerated with the basic schema format, but it can be verified with an assertion, as shown in the following example.

example.title: XPath Assertion example
example.programlisting: <xpathAssertion test="if (not(xsd:boolean(@external))) then @serverID else true()"> If the server is NOT external, then the serverID attribute is required. </xpathAssertion>

section.para: This assertion fails if the external value evaluates to false and the serverID attribute does not exist. If both conditions are met, the assertion passes.
For more information about XPath, see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/XPath.
The XPath context is the product element by default. You can change the context of the root of the entry by setting the scope attribute.
The following table describes the attributes that you can define for an XPath assertion.

tr.td: schema:XPathScope
Specifies the scope of an XPath assertion. The scope determines the context of the XPath assertion. The value can be either product or entry. The default value for this attribute is product.
When the value is entry, the variables $entry, $event, and $product are defined, each pointing to the respective part of the message.
xsd:string
Specifies the XPath test.
This attribute is required.

section.title: Versioning
section.para: The event and product nodes are version-controlled. Cloud Feeds can support events that contain different definitions for the event and product nodes simultaneously. This flexibility enables publishers to define a new event without breaking older events that have not yet adopted the new definition. The event and product versions are independent of each other.
For example, if you specify <event version="2">, Cloud Feeds applies different rules to the startTime and endTime attributes than if you specify <event version="1">.
You can define multiple versions for a specific product within a schema, as shown in the following example.

note.para: You can only update the version of an event if it is backwards compatible. If you want to update an event that is backwards incompatible, you need to create a new event. The purpose of the version number is to denote which schema rules should apply, and not to denote that a message is incompatible.

section.title: Allowed data types
section.para: The following table provides a list of allowed data types for product schema definitions.

tr.td: Specifies a Uniform Resource Identifier. This includes not only Uniform Resource Locators (URLs), but also Uniform Resource Names (URNs). Both relative and absolute URLs are allowed.
anyURI*
Specifies a whitespace-separated list of anyURI values.

Specifies an arbitrary sequence of bytes that has been encoded in ASCII characters using the Base-64 algorithm defined in RFC 2045. The letters A–Z and a–z, the digits 0–9, and the punctuation marks + and / are used to encode data according to an algorithm that maps four of these characters to three arbitrary bytes. The equal sign is used to pad data at the end if necessary.
Specifies a Boolean value.
boolean*
Specifies a whitespace-separated list of boolean values.
Specifies a signed integer that can be represented by a single byte. The minimum value of a byte is -128, and the maximum value is 127.
byte*
Specifies a whitespace-separated list of byte values.
The date type represents a specific day in history such as September 26, 2005. Dates are written in the form CCYY-MM-DD. For example, September 26, 2005 is written as 2005-09-26.
date*
Specifies a whitespace-separated list of date values.

Specifies a specific moment in history, such as 3:32 p.m., September 26, 2003. An optional time zone indicator in the form ±hh:mm can be suffixed to provide a time. For example, 2003-09-26T15:32:00-05:00 is 3:32 p.m., September 26, 2003 in the U.S. Eastern time zone.
dateTime*
Specifies a whitespace-separated list of dateTime values.
Specifies a decimal value that can be represented by an eight-byte floating-point number in IEEE 754 format. Values such as INF (infinity) and NaN (not a number) are allowed.
double*
Specifies a whitespace-separated list of double values.

Specifies a length of time, such as 15 minutes; 2 hours; or 3 years, 7 months, 2 days, 8 hours, 32 minutes, and 12 seconds. This value does not have a specific beginning or end. For more information, see the note following the table.
duration*
Specifies a whitespace-separated list of duration values.
Specifies a decimal value that can be represented by a four-byte floating-point number in IEEE 754 format. Values such as INF (infinity) and NaN (not a number) are allowed.
float*
Specifies a whitespace-separated list of float values.
gDay*
Specifies a whitespace-separated list of gDay values.
gMonth*
Specifies a whitespace-separated list of gMonth values.
gYear*
Specifies a whitespace-separated list of gYear values.
gMonthDay*
Specifies a whitespace-separated list of gMonthDay values.
gMonthYear*
Specifies a whitespace-separated list of gMonthYear values.
Specifies a signed integer that can be represented by four bytes. The minimum value of int is -2147483648, and the maximum value is 2147483647.
int*
Specifies a whitespace-separated list of int values.
Specifies an integer value of arbitrary size.
integer*
Specifies a whitespace-separated list of integer values.
Specifies a signed integer that can be represented by eight bytes. The minimum value of long is 9223372036854775807, and the maximum value is -9223372036854775808.
long*
Specifies a whitespace-separated list of long values.

Specifies a valid name. This name must be a string that consists exclusively of letters, digits, ideographs, underscores, hyphens, periods, and colons. Digits, hyphens, and periods may not be used to start a name, although they can be used inside the name.
Name*
Specifies a list of Name values.
Specifies a signed integer that can be represented by two bytes. The minimum value of a short is -32768, the maximum value is 32767.
short*
Specifies a whitespace-separated list of short values.
Specifies any sequence of characters.
string*
Specifies a list of string values.

Specifies a specific time of day on no particular day, such as 3:32 p.m. Times are written in the form ±hh:mm:ss.xxx using a 24-hour clock and as many fractions of a second as necessary. An optional time zone indicator in the form ±hh:mm may be suffixed to provide a time zone as an offset from Coordinated Universal Time (UTC). For example, 15:32:00-05:00 is 3:32 p.m., in the U.S. Eastern time zone. A Z can be used instead to indicate UTC: 00:00:00Z.
time*
Specifies a whitespace-separated list of time values.
Specifies an unsigned integer that can be represented by a single byte. The minimum value of unsignedByte is 0, and the maximum value is 255.
unsignedByte*
Specifies a whitespace-separated list of unsignedByte values.
Specifies an unsigned integer that can be represented by four bytes. The minimum value of unsignedInt is 0, and the maximum value is 4294967295.
unsignedInt*
Specifies a whitespace-separated list of unsignedInt values.
Specifies an unsigned integer that can be represented by eight bytes. The minimum value of unsignedLong is 0, and the maximum value is 18446744073709551615.
unsignedLong*
Specifies a whitespace-separated list of unsignedLong values.
Specifies an unsigned integer that can be represented by two bytes. The minimum value of unsignedShort is 0, and the maximum value is 65535.
unsignedShort*
Specifies a whitespace-separated list of unsignedShort values.
Specifies a dateTime constraint to be in the UTC time zone. That is the time zone offset must be 0 or the value must end with Z.
utcDateTime*
Specifies a whitespace-separated list of utcDateTime values.
Specifies a time constraint for the UTC time zone. The time zone offset must be 0 or the value must end with Z.
utcTime*
Specifies a whitespace-separated list of utcTime values.

Specifies a universally unique identifier in its canonical form: 32 hexadecimal digits, displayed in five groups separated by hyphens, in the form 8-4-4-4-12 for a total of 36 characters (32 digits and four hyphens). For example, 7eadda6a-9f3e-11e1-9ef4-77b6922f8866.
UUID*
Specifies a whitespace-separated list of UUID values.

note.para: Durations are represented by using the ISO-8601 standard format PnYnMnDTnHnMnS:

nY specifies the number of years.
nM specifies the number of months.
nD specifies the number of days.
nH specifies the number of hours.
nM specifies the number of minutes.
nS specifies the number of seconds.
The number of years, months, days, hours, minutes, and seconds are specified as nonnegative integers. The number of seconds is a decimal number with as many places after the decimal point as necessary. For example, in this format, 3 years, 7 months, 2 days, 8 hours, 32 minutes, and 12 seconds is written as P3Y7M2DT8H32M12S. Any values that are zero can be omitted. A duration of 2 years and 2 minutes can be written as P2YT2M. If there are no hours, minutes, or seconds, then the T is omitted. A duration of two years is written as P2Y. A leading minus sign before the P indicates a negative duration.

chapter.title: Preparing a feed for publication through Cloud Feeds
chapter.para: To define a new event, you need to submit a pull request on the https://github.com/rackerlabs/standard-usage-schemas repository.
To submit this pull request, you first need to complete the following steps:

listitem.para: Define your product schema.
Generate schemas and WADLs.
Add your feed to the allfeeds.wadl file.
Add message samples.
Add your feed to be included in the documentation.
Test your feed.

note.para: These steps assume that you have already set up a repository for Cloud Feeds in GitHub.

important.para: The standard-usage-schema build requires that you have Java 1.7 and Maven 3.0.5 installed on your computer.

section.title: Defining your product schema
section.para: After you have forked the repository and created a branch, you need to create a new XML file to define the product-specific schema.
Create a new file by using the sample_product_schemas/newProductName.xml naming convention, for example sample_product_schemas/nova.xml.
To define your product schema, complete the following steps:

listitem.para: Read the Product node section.
Define the productSchema node.
Define the description node.
Add the attributes and attribute groups for your product.

section.title: Defining the product schema node
section.para: When you create your product schema, you first need to define the product schema node. Defining the product schema node requires that you select a namespace for your product.
For a list of the attributes that are part of the product schema node, see Product schema node.

Following is an example of a product schema node: Product schema node example <productSchema xmlns="http://docs.rackspace.com/core/usage/schema" namespace="http://docs.rackspace.com/event/ebs/bu-team" serviceCode="EBS" type="CREATE UPDATE DELETE" version="1">

section.title: Defining the description node
section.para: After you have defined the product schema node, you need to add a description node. In the description node, you need to include a brief description of what kind of information is included in the event.
Following is an example of a description node. Description node example<description> Specifies the team mapping to the business unit. </description>

section.title: Defining the attributes and attribute groups
section.para: After you have defined the product schema and description nodes, you need to add the appropriate attibute and attribute group nodes for your product. For more information about attributes an attribute groups, see Attribute node and Attribute group.
Following is an example of a completed product schema file:

example.title: Completed product schema file example
example.programlisting:
<productSchema xmlns="http://docs.rackspace.com/core/usage/schema" namespace="http://docs.rackspace.com/event/ebs/bu-team" serviceCode="EBS" type="CREATE UPDATE DELETE" version="1"> <description> Specifies the team mapping to the business unit. </description> <attribute name="businessUnit" type="string" use="required" maxLength="150"> Specifies the business unit name. </attribute>
<attribute name="description" type="string" use="required" maxLength="255"> Specifies the description of the event. </attribute> <attributeGroup name="team" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"> <description> Specifies the team name and number which belongs to the listed business number. </description> <attribute name="name" type="string" use="required" maxLength="255"> Specifes the team name. </attribute> <attribute name="number" type="string" use="required" maxLength="150"> Specifies the team number. </attribute> </attributeGroup> </productSchema>

section.title: Adding the feed to the allfeeds.wadl file
section.para: After you have generated the appropriate schemas and WADLs, you need to add your feed to the allfeeds.wadl file.

Before adding your feed, you need to determine the validation mode of your feed:
product feed
validated feed
unvalidated feed
user access event feed
JSON CADF event feed
For more information about the validation modes, read Feed validation.

section.title: Adding a resource for a product feed
section.para:
To add a resource for a product feed, complete the following steps:
Open allfeeds.wadl and add a new resource for your feed.
If you want to make your feed available to internal users only, add the following resource:
<resource id="new_product" path="new_product/events" type="wadl/feed.wadl#AtomFeed wadl/product.wadl#[NewProductServiceCode]"/>
If you want to make your feed available to internal and external users, add the following resource:
<resource id="new_product" path="new_product/events" type="wadl/feed.wadl#AtomFeed wadl/product.wadl#[NewProductServiceCode] wadl/feed.wadl#TenantAtomFeed wadl/product.wadl#[NewProductServiceCode]Tenant"/>
To ensure that your feed can be tested, add the same resource types that you added in the preceding step to the functest1_events and functest2_events resources, as shown in the following example:
<resource id="functest1_events" path="functest1/events" type="wadl/feed.wadl#AtomFeed wadl/product.wadl#[NewProductServiceCode] wadl/feed.wadl#TenantAtomFeed wadl/product.wadl#[NewProductServiceCode]Tenant"/>

section.title: Adding samples
section.para: You can use Maven to generate sample responses and entries for each version of your product schema. To use Maven, ensure that you have version 3.0.5 installed. For more information, see the Maven 3.0.5. download site.
To generate samples, type the following command:
The sample files are generated under the message_samples/[feed_name] directory and use the following naming conventions:

listitem.para: $serviceCode-$nsPart-$eventType-v$versionNum-entry.xml
$serviceCode-$nsPart-$eventType-v$versionNum-response.xml
$serviceCode-$nsPart-$resourceType-$eventType-v$versionNum-entry.xml
$serviceCode-$nsPart-$resourceType-$eventType-v$versionNum-response.xml

section.para: The following table provides a breakdown of the different elements in the naming convention.

tr.td: Specifies the value of the serviceCode attribute in the product schema.
Specifies the last path segment in the product namespace. For example, if the product namespace is http://docs.rackspace.com/usage/widget, then the nsPart segment should be named widget.
Specifies the value of the resourceType attribute in the sample event XML file
Specifies the value of the type attribute of the event element in the sample event XML file.

section.para: An example file name is support-account-account_support-create-v1-entry.xml.

You might have to manually edit the generated samples to ensure that they are valid and semantically correct. For example, the product schema might contain XPath assertions that might not be met by the generated samples.
For generated samples, the following assumptions are made:

listitem.para: If the product schema requires a resourceId attribute, its value is set to 4a2b42f4-6c63-11e1-815b-7fcbcf67f549.
If the product schema contains xpathAssertion nodes, the assertions might not be satisfied by the generated content.
No optional nodes or attributes are generated.
The withEventType and withResource attributes are not processed.

section.title: Adding the feed to the documentation
section.para: As a next step, you need to add your feed to the documentation source files to ensure that the feed appears in the Cloud Feeds Developers Guide. These source files are located in the src/docbkx location.
Edit the following files depending on whether your feed is for internal or external users:

listitem.para: api-operations-internal.xml for internal users
api-operations-external.xml for external users

note.para: Different resources are required for internal and external feeds.

section.para: You need to add a section node to the appropriate source file that contains information specific to the feed, including a title attribute, as well as the corresponding URL and the appropriate resource hrefs.
